abstract:
Multi-touch attribution is a popular marketing science challenge. This
is a tricky problem to solve as the goal label we need to train for is a
latent variable i.e. can’t be directly observed in the real world. The
e-commerce industry is actively looking at using fancy ML techniques to
design a solution.

However, the question still remains, how do we know which methodology is
the best for Multi-touch Attribution?

`At Skyscanner, we have explored this problem space
further <https://medium.com/@SkyscannerEng/lets-make-roi-a-fair-%20game-e2eb734a9560>`__.
We use a *simulated marketing environment* to benchmark different
methodologies. In this talk I will discuss:

-  Benefits of benchmarking in a simulated environment.
-  How to build your own simulated environment.
-  Stress testing the solution with alternative scenarios.

An overview of this talk can be seen in `this
blog <http://bit.ly/Multi-%20TouchAttribution>`__ and `this research
poster <http://bit.ly/MTA-Poster>`__
description:
In this talk, I focus on a key challenge of designing a Multi-touch
attribution solution - Identifying which methodology is best for this
problem. This is a thorny issue as the variable we are trying to study
isn't directly observable. I’ll discuss a novel approach to tackle this
problem through simulated marketing environment.

HowToTrainYourMLSolutionForLatentVariables
==========================================
title: Multi-touch Attribution: What am I training for ?
